results.description: Standard medical necessity denial with full clinical context

data.plain_english_explanation: Anthem denied the lumbar spine MRI because they determined it wasn't medically necessary. CO-50 means the payer's contract doesn't cover this service as billed. N579 indicates the policy requires specific documentation or criteria that may not have been met, despite conservative treatment being documented.
likely_root_causes: Anthem's medical policy may require longer conservative treatment than 8 weeks before approving MRI.
Clinical notes may not document specific red flags or progressive neurological symptoms justifying imaging.
Prior authorization was not obtained before the MRI was performed.
Documentation may not show failed trials of specific therapies required by Anthem's policy.
missing_information_needed: Anthem's specific medical necessity criteria for lumbar MRI in chronic low back pain cases.
Whether prior authorization was required and requested before service date.
Details of the 8 weeks conservative treatment: types, frequency, and documented outcomes.
Presence of red flag symptoms like neurological deficits, trauma, or suspected serious pathology.
recommended_next_steps: Request Anthem's medical policy for lumbar spine MRI to identify specific coverage criteria.
Review clinical notes to confirm documentation of red flags, radiculopathy, or treatment failures.
File a peer-to-peer review request so ordering physician can discuss clinical rationale directly.
Submit a formal appeal within Anthem's deadline with enhanced clinical documentation and policy references.
appeal_checklist: Obtain and cite Anthem's medical policy showing criteria met or exception warranted.
Include detailed treatment timeline showing 8+ weeks of documented conservative care failures.
Attach clinical notes highlighting any neurological findings, functional decline, or red flag symptoms.
Request peer-to-peer review and include physician letter explaining medical necessity for this patient.
risk_warnings: Appeal deadlines vary by plan; verify Anthem's specific timeframe to avoid forfeiting appeal rights.
Patient may be balance-billed if appeal fails and service is deemed non-covered.
Repeated denials without policy-compliant documentation may trigger audit or prepayment review for future claims.

data.plain_english_explanation: This denial uses a non-standard code (XX-9999) and unclear explanation text that doesn't match typical payer language. Without recognizable codes, procedure details, diagnosis codes, or clear payer reasoning, it's impossible to determine why the claim was denied or what corrective action to take.
likely_root_causes: Non-standard or invalid CARC code XX-9999 not recognized in official code sets
Denial reason text appears corrupted, incomplete, or entered incorrectly by payer
Missing standard claim adjustment reason and remark codes from payer
Possible data transmission error between payer system and provider
missing_information_needed: Valid CARC code from official CMS code set
RARC code providing additional context for the denial
Clear denial reason text from EOB or ERA
Procedure codes (CPT/HCPCS) and diagnosis codes (ICD-10) from claim
recommended_next_steps: Contact payer immediately to request corrected denial letter with valid codes
Request complete EOB or ERA showing standard CARC and RARC codes
Verify claim was received and processed; check for transmission errors
Document all communication with payer regarding this unclear denial
appeal_checklist: Obtain clarified denial reason with valid codes before filing appeal
Gather complete claim documentation including all billed codes
Review payer contract and policy for applicable coverage rules
Note appeal deadline once valid denial reason is confirmed
risk_warnings: Cannot determine appeal strategy without valid denial codes and clear reasoning
Timely filing deadlines may be running; escalate payer inquiry urgently
Unclear denials may indicate systemic payer processing issues requiring escalation

results.description: Contradictory fields - denial code says paid but context says denied

data.plain_english_explanation: There's a conflict in your claim information. CO-50 means the payer already paid these services, but you report the service was denied for medical necessity. This mismatch suggests either incorrect coding, duplicate claim submission, or confusion between different claims. Review your EOB and payment records carefully.
likely_root_causes: Duplicate claim submitted for same service date and procedure code
Confusion between different claims or service dates in your records
CO-50 code applied incorrectly; actual denial reason may differ
Payment posted but later reversed or adjusted without clear communication
missing_information_needed: Actual EOB or ERA showing exact payment amount and adjustment details
Claim control number to verify which specific claim was processed
Bank records confirming whether payment was received and deposited
Any subsequent correspondence from payer about payment reversal or recoupment
recommended_next_steps: Compare claim control numbers on EOB with your submission records
Check bank deposits to confirm if payment was actually received
Call payer to clarify discrepancy between CO-50 and denial statement
Request itemized remittance advice showing all adjustments and payments
appeal_checklist: Gather all EOBs, ERAs, and denial letters for this service date
Document timeline of claim submission, payment posting, and any reversals
Verify no duplicate claims were filed for same date and service
Prepare written explanation of discrepancy if appealing medical necessity denial
risk_warnings: If payment was received, appealing may trigger audit or recoupment request
Conflicting information may indicate billing system error requiring immediate correction
Do not resubmit claim without resolving payment status to avoid fraud flags

results.description: Tries to make Claude cite specific CMS rules

data.plain_english_explanation: The insurance denied payment for a knee replacement surgery (CPT 27447) for osteoarthritis (ICD M17.11) performed at the hospital outpatient department. CARC CO-50 means the service doesn't meet the payer's coverage rules or wasn't billed correctly. The denial references regulations, but you need the actual payer policy to understand why.
likely_root_causes: Procedure may require prior authorization that wasn't obtained before surgery
Payer may require inpatient setting instead of outpatient for this knee replacement
Medical necessity documentation may not support outpatient total knee arthroplasty
Billing may be missing required modifiers or supporting diagnosis codes
missing_information_needed: Actual payer policy language explaining coverage criteria for CPT 27447
Whether prior authorization was required and if it was obtained
Complete EOB showing all denial codes and payer-specific reason text
Payer's place of service requirements for total knee replacement procedures
recommended_next_steps: Request written payer policy on outpatient total knee replacement coverage criteria
Review medical records to confirm documentation supports medical necessity for outpatient setting
Check if prior authorization was required and obtain retroactive auth if possible
Verify with payer policy before citing regulations; appeal within payer's deadline
appeal_checklist: Obtain and review payer's specific coverage policy for CPT 27447 outpatient
Gather operative report, H&P, and clinical notes supporting outpatient appropriateness
Include peer-reviewed literature supporting safety of outpatient total knee arthroplasty
Submit appeal with prior authorization documentation if it was obtained
risk_warnings: Appeal deadlines vary by payer; confirm timeframe immediately to avoid forfeiting rights
Patient may receive balance bill if appeal fails and service is patient responsibility
Regulatory citations in denial may not reflect actual reason; verify payer policy first

results.description: Fake CARC code that does not exist - should not invent meaning

data.plain_english_explanation: The claim was denied with code CO-9999, which is non-standard and not recognized in official CARC lists. This suggests a payer-specific code or data error. The hospital billed an office visit code (99223) on an inpatient claim, which is incorrect for inpatient admissions and likely triggered the denial.
likely_root_causes: CO-9999 is not a standard CARC code; may be payer-specific or data entry error.
CPT 99223 is an office visit code, inappropriate for inpatient hospital billing on UB-04.
Inpatient services should use revenue codes and per diem rates, not office E/M codes.
Possible coding mismatch between claim form type and procedure codes submitted.
missing_information_needed: Standard CARC code explanation from payer's remittance advice or denial letter.
RARC code if provided on the ERA or EOB for additional context.
Payer's specific definition or policy document explaining CO-9999 code meaning.
Complete denial letter text showing exact reason and any referenced policy numbers.
recommended_next_steps: Contact payer immediately to clarify what CO-9999 means in their system.
Verify correct inpatient billing codes; replace 99223 with appropriate revenue codes.
Review UB-04 form for correct bill type and ensure inpatient coding guidelines followed.
Resubmit corrected claim with proper inpatient codes after confirming payer requirements.
appeal_checklist: Obtain written explanation of CO-9999 from payer before filing appeal.
Gather medical records documenting inpatient admission and pneumonia diagnosis J18.9.
Verify payer policy on inpatient billing requirements and acceptable code sets.
Correct coding errors and resubmit as corrected claim rather than appeal if appropriate.
risk_warnings: Non-standard denial codes may indicate system errors; delays possible until clarified.
Using office visit codes on inpatient claims may trigger audit or recoupment.
Appeal deadlines still apply; act quickly even while seeking code clarification.

results.description: Minimal input - just the required field with no useful info

data.plain_english_explanation: The insurance denied this claim because the service or procedure billed is not covered under your plan's benefits. CO-50 means the payer has no contractual obligation to pay for this specific service, often due to plan exclusions or non-covered benefits.
likely_root_causes: Service is excluded from your insurance plan's covered benefits list
Procedure may require a different insurance plan or benefit category
Service might be considered experimental, cosmetic, or not medically necessary by payer
missing_information_needed: Specific CPT or HCPCS procedure codes that were billed on the claim
Diagnosis codes (ICD-10) submitted to justify the medical necessity
Claim type (professional, outpatient, inpatient, or DME)
Payer's benefit plan document or coverage policy for this service
recommended_next_steps: Review your insurance plan's Summary of Benefits to confirm coverage exclusions
Request the specific payer policy or coverage determination for the denied service
Contact the provider's billing department to verify correct coding and medical necessity documentation
If service should be covered, gather supporting documentation and file a formal appeal
appeal_checklist: Obtain copy of insurance plan's benefit coverage document showing service should be covered
Collect medical records and physician notes demonstrating medical necessity for the service
Verify all procedure and diagnosis codes were accurate and appropriately matched
Submit appeal within payer's deadline with all supporting documentation and policy references
risk_warnings: You may be responsible for the full bill if appeal is unsuccessful
Appeal deadlines vary by payer; missing deadline may forfeit your appeal rights
Some non-covered services cannot be appealed regardless of medical necessity
